Award.AwardTitle: Support for Junior Investigators at the Orthopaedic Research Society (ORS) Sun Valley Workshop on Musculoskeletal Biology; Sun Valley, Idaho; August 7-10, 2016

Division.LongName: Div Of Civil, Mechanical, & Manufact Inn

Award.AbstractNarration:
The Sun Valley Workshops on Skeletal Biology emphasizes active participation of junior faculty and students/fellows. The award "Support for Junior Investigators at the Orthopaedic Research Society (ORS) Sun Valley Workshop on Musculoskeletal Biology; Sun Valley, Idaho; August 7-10, 2016" will be organized around problem solving, rather than just presentation and extensive discussion. The meeting will institute a new program to highlight posters presented at the workshop: "Blue Ribbon Sun Valley Posters." Ten posters will be chosen for 3 minute summary presentations by the authors. The intent is to highlight the most significant posters, in many cases young investigator posters, and generate interest in visiting the posters. Two of these sessions are planned.

The musculoskeletal system (muscles, tendon, bone) is highly sensitive to mechanical load and many younger investigators from previous Sun Valley meetings have submitted applications to the Biomechanics and Mechanobiology program. It continues as one of the important training venues for future scientists in the area of mechanobiology of the musculoskeletal system.

POR.DRECONTENT:
ORS Sun Valley Workshop: Musculoskeletal Biology, 2016

 

The objective of the Sun Valley Workshop is to improve understanding across the many disciplines that study skeletal biology, to provide new perspectives that lead to prevention and/or treatment of skeletal diseases, and to develop interdisciplinary collaborations, especially for younger scientists and scientists new to the field. The workshop receives support from the NIH, NSF, ASBMR, and AAA.

 

In 2016, it was the 46th Sun Valley Workshop and the 51st year since the first Workshop was held in 1965. The theme this year was “Solving Problems, Suggesting Solutions.” Four sessions addressed relevant current problems, including experimental reproducibility, overdiagnosis of osteoporosis, muscle and bone health in cancer survivors and translational models for bone-muscle cross-talk studies. Further, we selected a problem in endocrinology (Hypophosphatasia) and one in orthopaedics (Self-repair of tendons and ligaments). Many opportunities are provided for junior investigators to interact with more senior investigators. The Plenary Lecture and RIB Award was presented Sunday morning

 

27 posters were presented this year; and 24 awards were given to junior investigators, who presented their work orally or in a poster. Awards included 12 Jee Awards; 9 ASBMR/Harold M. Frost Awards; 1 award for osteoarthritis research; 3 Under-represented Minority Travel Awards; and 1 young investigator award in honor of Dr. Charles Turner.

 

The Career Development session geared toward junior investigators, chaired by Dr. M. van der Meulen, focused on Tenure and the Tenure Dossier. It included discussions of mentoring, resources and personnel, with a panel comprised of Drs. G. Lester, T. Bellido, G. Krishnan, B. Williams, J.L. Millan, D. Roodman, S. Bloomfield. More than 40 attendees were at this session; 25% graduate students, 55% postdoctoral fellows, and 20% Assistant Professors. 

 

Continuing a tradition of mentorship, lunches were arranged between young investigators award winners and more senior investigators selected from invited speakers and senior investigators who attended the meeting, who served as mentors. As an additional aspect of mentorship, we appointed a pre-workshop young investigator mentor, who worked prior to the Workshop with the young investigators on content and length of their presentations.  

 

We are committed to the active participation of women in these Workshops. Women have constituted about 32-37% of the participants. In 2016, 39% of the participants were women. Three of seven session chairs (43%) were women. Three of the eight members of the Advisory Board are women.   

 

In 2016, 8% of the participants were under-represented minorities (1 African-American and 3 Hispanic). We will continue to support URMs with young investigator and travel awards.  We will contact labs personally to make them aware that there will be at least 5 awards available only to underrepresented minorities.

 

These are some of the comments received for the 2016 meeting:

 

  1. Excellent meeting. Always a unique opportunity to discuss important problems with leaders in the field and to foster new collaboration and colleague networks.
  2. I really love the format and content of this workshop. Other conferences I have attended do not address complications with translation, such availability of funding and lack of reproducibility and that becomes frustrating from the industry point of view. It was an honor to interact with such knowledgeable veterans in the field. This workshop is fantastic and I hope to attend again.
  3. I thought it was a fantastic conference. I am a young investigator and I met many people, other young investigators and senior investigators. I felt comfortable starting conversations with people and I made many new contacts and friends.
  4. This meeting is much better than a large meeting where there are many lectures but little discussion. This meeting promotes understanding the topics covered in a session. Since there is so much information and learning going on, it is helpful to have afternoons off to mull through what was learned in morning sessions and to regenerate for more learning in the evening session!
  5. It was one of the best meetings I have ever attended. The format (questions allowed and encouraged) made for a very lively, interesting and intellectually vibrant meeting.
  6. This is a very high value meeting both because of the excellent speakers and program content and because of the format. Informal discussions are so important for meaningful research yet most meetings are so filled with must-see talks that interactions between attendees are usually glancing at best. The free time in the afternoons and the multiple opportunities for networking/interacting are invaluable. Please do not change this workshop, and please do not let it grow too large.

 

 

Respectfully submitted,

 

Teresita Bellido, PhD

Co-Director, Sun Valley Workshop on Musculoskeletal Biology                   739 words, max 800 wo
